Here is an example of how you could use R to forecast GDP using a time series model while adjusting for exogenous variables:
```
# First, install and load the necessary libraries
install.packages("forecast")
library(forecast)

# Next, import the GDP data,exogenous variables and create time series objects
gdp_data <- read.csv("gdp_data.csv")
gdp_ts <- ts(gdp_data$value, start = c(year(gdp_data$date[1]), quarter(gdp_data$date[1])), frequency = 4)

cpi_data <- read.csv("cpi_data.csv")
cpi_ts <- ts(cpi_data$value, start = c(year(cpi_data$date[1]), quarter(cpi_data$date[1])), frequency = 4)

ppi_data <- read.csv("ppi_data.csv")
ppi_ts <- ts(ppi_data$value, start = c(year(ppi_data$date[1]), quarter(ppi_data$date[1])), frequency = 4)

trade_balance_data <- read.csv("trade_balance_data.csv")
trade_balance_ts <- ts(trade_balance_data$value, start = c(year(trade_balance_data$date[1]), quarter(trade_balance_data$date[1])), frequency = 4)

# Check for stationarity
adf.test(gdp_ts)
kpss.test(gdp_ts)

# If the data is non-stationary, difference the data to make it stationary
gdp_ts_diff <- diff(gdp_ts)

# Create a SARIMAX model with the GDP data and exogenous variable
exog_ts <- cbind(cpi_ts, ppi_ts, trade_balance_ts)
best_model <- auto.arima(gdp_ts_diff, xreg = exog_ts)

# Use the selected model to forecast future GDP values
forecast_horizon <- 5
forecast_gdp <- forecast(best_model, h=forecast_horizon)
plot(forecast_gdp)
```
In this example, the GDP data, Consumer price index(CPI), Producer price index(PPI), Trade balance data are imported and time series objects
